text.p: Italy's Wilfried Pallhuber won his first individual gold medal in the opening men's 10 kilometres sprint at the world biathlon championships on Saturday.
Pallhuber, a policeman, who is 14th in the overall biathlon World Cup standings, recorded 26 minutes 24.4 seconds and a perfect shooting record.
He finished 16.8 seconds ahead of compatriot Rene Cattarinussi, for whom one miss in the prone shooting event and a subsequent penalty lap cost him the gold.

Oleg Ryzhenkov of Belarus, last year's world championship gold medallist in the team event, finished third, 18.3 seconds behind the winner after having to run an additional two penalty laps for misses in the standing shooting.
Olga Romasko of Russia, a professional soldier from Krasnoyrask and the defending world champion, won the women's 7.5-km sprint in 21:16.8 with one miss and a penalty lap.
Olena Zubrilova of Ukraine finished second in the women's event in 21:59.5 ahead of Sweden's Magdelana Forsberg, who was three seconds behind, but with two penalty laps.
The top 45 from the men's and women's sprints qualified for a place in Sunday's pursuit event which has been included for the first time in a world championship.
